advert.description: <br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH AD (SEPT. 1983)</strong></font><br><blockquote>"The amazing TI-99/4A.<br> A computer for 1800fr"</blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> 1976 PRICE LIST</strong></font><br><blockquote>Notice that the 16K static RAM expansion is more expensive than the computer itself.<p class="petitgris">Thanks to <b>Mark Thompson</b></p></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> GERMAN ADVERT (1983)</strong></font><br><blockquote>1983 Hannover show advert. <br><br> Advert said that 30,000 Kaypro II systems were already sold in the U.S.A.</blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> UK ADVERT (STUPID !)</strong></font><br><blockquote>Dated august 1982<p class="petitgris">Thanks to <a href="http://wotsit.thingy.com/haj/">Howard Jones</a> for this picture.</p></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> 1977 ADVERT #2</strong></font><br><blockquote>This ad uses actors, except for IMSAI's Finance Director Hersch Mandelman as the "Milk Man".</blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> NEW ZEALAND AD. (1980)</strong></font><br><blockquote>Nice advert, but nothing seems right in the picture...<p class="petitgris">Thanks to <b>Murray Muffat</b> from New Zeland</p></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> U.K. AD. 1984</strong></font><br><blockquote>In the same magazine, Robert Hardling, the marketing manager of Atari Corporation said:<br><br><font color="#666666"> I envisage the situation where each house in 20 years time will have two, three or maybe more computers, ranging from a basic game machine through a home computer for education and home management and culminating in a fully fledged hyghly sophisticated computing work-station.<br> In the future, there may be only 3-4 major worldwide manufacturers. The IBM's, Apple's, Commodore's and Atari's of the world.</blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> GERMAN AD #2</strong></font><br><blockquote>"Large achievement capability and high versatility with 64kb RAM." <p class="petitgris">Courtesy of <b>www.sharpmz.org</b></p></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> CHARLIE CHAPLIN #4 </strong></font><br><blockquote>In June 1983, IBM was still seeking independant programmers.<br> Advert said:<br><br><font color="#666666" The envelope please.<br> There's an acceptance letter inside. And a check that could have your name on it. (If we select your program, that is.)<br> But remember. We pick our winners carefully... </font> </blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> JAPANESE ADVERT</strong></font><br><blockquote><p class="petitgris">Thanks to <a href="http://mayura.jp/blog" target="_blank">Mayura Labo</a> for this picture</p></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH ADVERT.</strong></font><br><blockquote>"For 1690 FF, wire all your family to the Laser 310"</blockquote>

computer.description:
In the early 70s, the British government whished an English computer company could compete with the world major manufacturers. Some years later, the ICL company became one of the larger manufacturer of computers in Europe and did really compete with U.S. companies. In 1980, before the ICL Personal Computer was born, the company met serious financial problems, the English government paid several million pounds and ICL asked the British RAIR CIE to provide the ICL-PC hardware. This ICL Personal Computer is thus exactly the same machine as the RAIR Black Box system, a backplane 8085 based system using a serial video terminal as video display, and CP/M (single user) or MP/M (multi-user) operating systems. Two series were released. The PC1 series is the model pictured here. The PC2 series was the same design case as the ICL PC Quattro. This used an Intel or AMD 8085AH-2 CPU at 5MHZ
The model numbers for the PC1 series were: Model 10 (pictured here) - 64 KB RAM, 2 x 5.25" FDD, CP/M O.S. Model 30 with a 5 MB hard disc, CP/M O.S. Model 31 64 KB RAM, three users, 5 MB hard disc, MP/M O.S. Model 32 256 KB RAM, three users, 10 MB hard disc, MP/M O.S.
Those of the PC2 series were: Model 15 64 KB RAM, 2 x 5.25" FDD, CP/M O.S. Model 25 with a 5 MB hard disc, CP/M O.S. Model 26 64 KB RAM, three users, 5 MB hard disc, MP/M O.S. Model 35 256 KB RAM, three users, 10 MB hard disc, MP/M O.S.
Agnus WR Gulliver reports us: There were a few simple games written for it, mostly text based (what do you expect, it uses CP/M), but it's main use was of course as an office machine. I recall it being a slow machine to use, even boot-up took about a minute. You had to be very careful with the hard disk because it didn't have auto-parking heads. After it was switched off you had to wait about a minute to switch it on again.
According to K.-L. Butte,there were 3 different models of it marking the 3 major development steps: The first incarnation wit 8085 and MP/M, the second with 8088 and Concurrent CP/M and the third with 8086 and Concurrent CP/M.
computer.keyboard: Full-stroke 102 keys with function keys and numeric keypad
computer.media: 2 x 5.25'' 256 KB Double sided / Double density FDD
computer.name: Personal computer
computer.ports: 2 x serial ports. Serial printer and keyboard on terminal

shot.description: <br><font color="red"><strong>> COMPLETE SYSTEM</strong></font><br><blockquote>Complete running system with an ICL dot matrix printer, actually an Oki Microline 82, and a Maplin 300 baud modem.</blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> BACK</strong></font><br><blockquote><b>(1)</b> Keyboard connector<br> <b>(2)</b> Parallel printer DB25 connector<br> <b>(3)</b> Host/serial DB25 connector<br> <b>(4)</b> 2 x serial port. The upper one is dedicated to the video terminal</blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> INSIDE SYSTEM</strong></font><br><blockquote><b>(1)</b> The backplane features 8 connectors and uses a specific RAIR format<br> <b>(2)</b> Serial board<br> <b>(3)</b> 64 KB memory board. Uses 32 x 4116 RAM chips<br> <b>(4)</b> Processor board<br> <b>(5)</b> Floppy disk controller board<br> <b>(6)</b> Switching power supply unit and large fan<br> <b>(7)</b> 2 x 5.25" Tandon FDD. Double side, double density, 48TPI, 780 KB models.</blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> INSIDE VIDEO TERMINAL</strong></font><br><blockquote>The video terminal features a complete computer board including a 8085 processor, ROM an RAM memory, and programmable I/O ports.</blockquote>

computer.vram: Depending on the video terminal used
